Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

eventName: SOLD OUT “The Architecture of Galt” - Soup and Stroll
description: Come for the walk, stay for the soup!What could be better on a chilly fall day, than an interesting and enlightening stroll, followed by a warm bowl of hearty and delicious Scotch Broth soup in our cozy Cottage on the banks of the Grand?Plan to join us for a fall walking tour of the area surrounding McDougall Cottage. We’ll explore the architecture of “The Granite City”, looking at how Scottish masons constructed the stone houses that the workers and business owners lived in and that the early industries of the areas were built on. We’ll talk about what happens when architectural heritage of an area is lost and how we can protect it for future generations. Finally, we’ll walk through the neighborhoods that host the baronial houses atop the hills of West Galt and then head back to the Cottage for a tasty treat.This walking tour may include hills, stairs and uneven terrain. Participants should dress for the weather. Phones are recommended, but not required, to access additional information on the sites we’ll be visiting. Note: No washroom facilities available during tour.Pre-registration is required and space is limited, so register early!

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. An evening of chills and thrills with two award-winning authors.Meet two award-winning authors, learn more about their latest books and stay to enjoy the refreshments, book giveaways, and more.Stop by the Rookery Books table to purchase novels and get them signed by your favourite author as a memento of this thrilling evening.The Lie Maker By Linwood BarclayIn this twisty, fast-paced thriller from the New York Times bestselling author of Find You First and Take Your Breath Away, a man desperately tries to track down his father—who was taken into witness protection years ago—before his enemies can get to him.Your dad’s not a good person. Your dad killed people, son.These are some of the last words Jack Givins’ father spoke to him before he was whisked away by witness protection, leaving Jack and his mother to pick up the shattered pieces of their lives as best they could.Years later, Jack is a grown man with problems of his own. He’s a talented but struggling author, barely scraping by on the royalties from his moderately successful first book. So when the U.S. Marshals approach him with a lucrative opportunity, he’s in no position to turn them down. They’re recruiting writers like Jack to create false histories for people in witness protection—people like Jack’s father.The coincidence is astonishing to Jack at first, but he soon realizes this may be a chance to find his dad. Only there’s one problem—Jack’s father hasn’t made contact with his handlers recently, and they have no idea where he is. He could be in serious danger, and Jack may be the only one who can find him.But how will he find a man he’s never truly known? A man who has done terrible things in his lifetime and made some deadly enemies in the process—enemies who wouldn’t think twice about using his own son against him.The Manor House By Gilly MacmillanChildhood sweethearts Nicole and Tom are a normal, loving couple—until a massive lottery win changes their lives overnight.Soon they’ve moved into a custom-built state-of-the-art Glass Barn on the stunning grounds of Lancaut Manor in Gloucestershire. They have fancy cars, expensive hobbies, and an exclusive lifestyle they never could have imagined.But this dream world quickly turns into a nightmare when Tom is found dead in the swimming pool.Nicole is devastated. Tom is her rock. And their beautiful barn —with all its smart features that never seem to work for her—is beginning to feel very lonely.Was Tom’s death a tragic accident or was it something worse? And is her life in danger as well?Registration is required to confirm attendance. Limited entry without registration may be available at the door.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |
Adults |EVENT TYPE: |

Meet Cambridge Career Connections online for workshops on topics related to job searching and career development.All workshops are virtual, drop-in, and no registration is required. Join the program at the scheduled time on Zoom.September 19: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.September 26: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.October 3: Interview SkillsThe Interview Skills workshop offers an overview of the various elements of the entire interview process. Looking at all stages of the interview process, participants will learn the “Do’s and Don’ts” of the interview process. After attending this interactive workshop, individuals will be more confident entering an interview, know how to make a good first impression, and have the building blocks to answer interview questions appropriately.October 10: Job Searching, Networking, and Social MediaIn the interactive Job Searching and Networking workshop, participants will explore and gain knowledge about how to access the hidden vs. open job markets. Participants will explore five topics, some of which include exploring traditional vs. non-traditional job searching and the application process.Oct 17: Employer ExpectationsIn the Employer Expectations workshop, participants will explore various “Do’s and Don’ts” on how to keep a job and what employers look for and expect of their employees. From general attitude to learning about styles of manager feedback, clients will learn tips and tricks to help them meet expectations and keep their job.October 24: Getting to know your PaycheckThe interactive Getting To Know Your Paycheck workshop offers an introduction to the tax deductions that you expect to have taken off of your employment income. Looking at the breakdown of a pay stub may be confusing and stressful, especially when starting a new job. After attending this workshop, we hope that individuals have a greater understanding of what tax deductions will be taken off of employment income, why these deductions exist, and roughly how they are calculated.October 31: Workplace WellnessBe informed on how to manage workplace stress and anxiety. Not only is it important to recognize the symptoms of workplace stress, but the steps we can take to address and learn what causes it. Learn about the tips and tricks for a healthy self-care routine and how we can work to reduce/remove the source of these stressors.November 7: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.November 14: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

eventName: CTAL: Blinded by the Might: The Women behind Hitler
description:
Although Hitler’s inner political circle was composed entirely of men, it is difficult to understand Hitler without knowing about the women who influenced him.From childhood to death, Hitler was surrounded by women who helped him on his path to becoming dictator and warlord. We are most familiar with three of them: his mother, Klara; his niece, Geli; and his long-time girlfriend, Eva, but there were many others who played a significant role in Hitler’s life. In this talk, we will discuss the background of these women, why they fell under Hitler’s spell, how they helped further his career, and the price that they paid for being an intimate of Hitler.About Prof. Gary BruceProf. Bruce is currently developing two research projects. The first project seeks to return historical focus to the early years of the Nazi regime through an examination of violence meted out by the state, and the manner by which the German populace responded to state-sanctioned murder prior to the Holocaust. The second project deals with memory and memorialization of the Nazi era as exhibited in historic sites in and around Berlin, with a focus on the Ravensbrück memorial site. His background includes a B.A. Queen's University, M.A. University of New Brunswick, PhD McGill University, studied abroad at the University of Glasgow and the University of LeipzigAbout Cambridge Third Age Learning (CTAL)Third Age Learning (TAL) is a movement that encourages learning and discovery experiences for those in the “third age”—the stage in one’s life beyond full-time employment. Cambridge Third Age Learning is a volunteer-led committee that cultivates opportunities for discussion and engages the expertise of local university professors and community professionals, CTAL supports those who have an intellectual curiosity and an interest in life-long learning.AGE GROUP: |

Award-winning Canadian Military Historian, Tim Cook, will join us virtually from Ottawa.Idea Exchange is pleased to welcome back Canadian Military Historian, Tim Cook, joining us virtually from Ottawa.  Tim has thirteen successfully published books about the military history of Canada.Please register to join us virtually, or register to join us in person at the Old Post Office where we'll be screening the virtual program.Copies of the book will be available to purchase from Rookery Books at the in-person event.Canada’s Great War Fallen: Marking Their PlaceIn advance of Remembrance Day, Dr. Tim Cook, Chief Historian of the Canadian War Museum and author or editor of 17 books of Canadian military history, will offer an illustrated presentation on grief, loss, and commemoration after Canada’s Great War. When the terrible war ended on 11 November 1918, Canadians were confronted with marking the sacrifice of the 620,000 who served, and the 66,000 who were killed. Grappling with the meaning of the war, Canadians built memorials across the country, created new symbols of commemoration, and forged new events like Armistice Day (later renamed Remembrance Day). Dr. Cook will use the Great War as a means to better understand the ways that Canadian's have faced mass death and loss in war, and how they continue to reflect on the Great War’s place in the country’s social memory.Registration is required to confirm attendance. Limited entry to the screening without registration may be available at the door.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

eventName: SOLD OUT - Moccasin Making Workshop with Haudenosaunee Artisan Susan Hill
description: Have you ever wondered what it takes to make moccasins? Do you want to have your own customized moccasins that you put together yourself? If so then make sure to join us for the kickoff of “Rock Your Mocs” week at a moccasin making workshop with, Haudenosaunee artisan, Susan Hill.In the space of 4 hours, using cut-to-measure pieces of buffalo and moose hide (hides will be either black, brown or tan, depending on availability) Susan will walk you through the process of piecing and sewing your moccasins together. Make a pair for yourself, or for someone you care about (what a GREAT Christmas gift these would make!).When you register, please be sure to indicate your shoe size so the moccasin components can be pre-cut to size.Reservations are required as space is limited.In order for Susan to prepare materials for the workshop, REGISTRATION CLOSES ON OCTOBER 29TH!Be sure to not miss out and reserve your spot today!

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Meet Cambridge Career Connections online for workshops on topics related to job searching and career development.All workshops are virtual, drop-in, and no registration is required. Join the program at the scheduled time on Zoom.September 19: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.September 26: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.October 3: Interview SkillsThe Interview Skills workshop offers an overview of the various elements of the entire interview process. Looking at all stages of the interview process, participants will learn the “Do’s and Don’ts” of the interview process. After attending this interactive workshop, individuals will be more confident entering an interview, know how to make a good first impression, and have the building blocks to answer interview questions appropriately.October 10: Job Searching, Networking, and Social MediaIn the interactive Job Searching and Networking workshop, participants will explore and gain knowledge about how to access the hidden vs. open job markets. Participants will explore five topics, some of which include exploring traditional vs. non-traditional job searching and the application process.Oct 17: Employer ExpectationsIn the Employer Expectations workshop, participants will explore various “Do’s and Don’ts” on how to keep a job and what employers look for and expect of their employees. From general attitude to learning about styles of manager feedback, clients will learn tips and tricks to help them meet expectations and keep their job.October 24: Getting to know your PaycheckThe interactive Getting To Know Your Paycheck workshop offers an introduction to the tax deductions that you expect to have taken off of your employment income. Looking at the breakdown of a pay stub may be confusing and stressful, especially when starting a new job. After attending this workshop, we hope that individuals have a greater understanding of what tax deductions will be taken off of employment income, why these deductions exist, and roughly how they are calculated.October 31: Workplace WellnessBe informed on how to manage workplace stress and anxiety. Not only is it important to recognize the symptoms of workplace stress, but the steps we can take to address and learn what causes it. Learn about the tips and tricks for a healthy self-care routine and how we can work to reduce/remove the source of these stressors.November 7: Resume DevelopmentIn the Resume Development workshop, participants will explore various resume styles including the structure and content of both chronological and functional resumes, while determining what style is appropriate. Participants will also learn resume “Do’s and Don’ts” as well as what should be included in a cover letter in this interactive workshop.November 14: Meet and GreetDiscover how the Cambridge Career Connections employment team is able to assist Cambridge residents with their employment and job search needs. Learn about our pre-employment supports and how you can access these free services. In addition, you will learn about the wide variety of programs and supports Idea Exchange offers and how they inspire our community through reading, arts, innovation, and learning.Cost: FreeAGE GROUP: |

Become a leader in your community and share your unique perspective.Focus on Leadership is designed to provide training for racialized women interested in becoming leaders of tomorrow. Our training will focus on how to become a board member and increase networking abilities to gain access to employment opportunities focusing on team-building, problem-solving, and decision-making. As board members, you will be able to apply these skills to bring about change in the community.The topics covered are:1. Types of Boards: Governance vs. Operations2. Board Responsibilities3. eventName: WRCF Do More Good Dialogue - Building Community: It’s more than housing
description: How can we build more community as we build more housing? Can we reimagine our public parks, libraries, recreation centers, and trails to connect people of all backgrounds, to cultivate trust and to create more resilient communities? Can we transform shared civic assets to foster engagement, equity, sustainability and joy? Join Waterloo Region Community Foundation on Thursday, November 16, 2023 from 4-6 pm for their next in-person Do More Good Dialogue to delve into these issues.

LGBTQ2S+ identifying individuals are invited to explore a different creative project each month in a fun and safe space.Join us for this fun, casual program. Together we will explore a new creative project with a guest artist each month. Registration is limited to 2SLGBTQ+ identifying people in Waterloo Region. This month we are exploring printmaking with Alyssa Pisciotto. No experience is necessary and all materials are provided.About the instructor:Alyssa Pisciotto is a queer artist from LaSalle, Ontario and now resides in Toronto. She graduated from OCAD University in 2016 with a Bachelor of Fine Arts, majoring in Drawing and Painting and minoring in Printmaking. Painting and printmaking are her primary practice. Her current work revolves around themes of colour, line and shape, and how they interact with one another. Alyssa has shown in galleries across Canada and the United States, and has been a part of a year-long special exhibition at TheMuseum in Kitchener, Ontario. Alyssa is currently working with The Art Gallery of Windsor to create and deliver arts programing with their Art With Heart workshop series.This program is offered in partnership with Spectrum, Waterloo Region’s Rainbow Community Space.AGE GROUP: |

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

Visible Mending is guaranteed to liven up your wardrobe!Local mending enthusiast Elysha will guide you through the basics of garment repair. We’ll talk about buttons, zippers, and darning but the hands-on component will focus on learning basic stitches to create hand-stitched patching techniques. You’ll bring something to mend: anything with a knee, elbow, or other hole is a perfect candidate for a patch.Participants will bring a garment in need of repair. All other supplies will be provided. All skill levels are welcome including complete beginners to the world of sewing and mending.Meet the Instructor:Elysha Schuhbauer is a textile artist and mender based in Kitchener, Ontario. Elysha explores visible mending as a way to forge a unique personal style while challenging fast fashion and finding value in everyday objects. Working with secondhand materials centres their unquenchable creative desires while maintaining an intentionally minimal environmental impact. Elysha is the founder of mending and upcycling business Worth Mending, which focuses on spreading the good word of sustainability, slow fashion, and skill-building through visible mending workshops and the popular upcycled Swift Darning Loom. Elysha is also a passionate cyclist and naturalist who enjoys exploring the outdoors in any season looking for interesting birds, bugs, plants, fungi, and geography.AGE GROUP: |

Meera Sethi discusses her artistic practice with Contemporary Art Historian, Dr. Natasha BissonauthIn conjunction with Meera Sethi's exhibitions at Cambridge Art Galleries, Dr. Natasha Bissonauth will join Meera in discussing aspects of her current research and artistic practice.About the Presenters:Meera Sethi is a contemporary artist with an intuitive and research-based practice that moves across painting, drawing, fibre, illustration, performance, and social practice. Her work sits at the intersection of the subjugated body and histories of cloth with a particular focus on South Asia and it’s diasporas. She is interested in the making, wearing, and disposing of cloth; clothing as a form of self-expression and resistance; and the ways by which textile is constituted over vast geographies. Through her work, she delves deep into our understanding of the self, the body, cloth and clothing, including it’s histories, resonances, and possibilities. Her work has been exhibited nationally and internationally and can be found in the permanent collection of the Royal Ontario Museum and the Wedge Collection. She lives and works in the traditional territory of the Anishinaabe, Haudenosaunee, Huron-Wendat, and Mississaugas of the Credit River. Her exhibitions Cotton Exchange and Outerwhere are currently on view at Cambridge Art Galleries.Dr Natasha Bissonauth teaches Visual Art and Art History at York University (Toronto). Prior to York University she was Assistant Professor of Women’s Gender, and Sexuality Studies at the College of Wooster. She received her Ph.D. in Art History at Cornell University and her research centers queer, trans, and feminist contemporary art practices with expertise in South Asia and its multiple diasporas. Recent research interests expand on indenture studies, archival work, and material cultures. She is currently working on a book project that investigates aesthetic encounters with archival fragments in ways that creates passage between legacies of immigration and indenture. By threading ‘areas’ like South Asia, the Caribbean, and Mauritius, Black and brown seams within the discipline emerge. Select publications include “Sunil Gupta’s Sun City: An Exercise in Camping Orientalism” (Art Journal;  2019), “The Future of Museological Display: Chitra Ganesh’s Speculative Encounters” (in Museums, Sexuality, and Gender Activism, 2020), and “The Dissent of Play: Lotahs in the Museum” (South Asia, 2020). Recent articles examine gender and indenture aesthetics in Kama La Mackerel’s poetry and Renluka Maharaj’s visual practice. Several exhibition catalog essays are forthcoming, on the artistic practice of Zanele Muholi, Chitra Ganesh, and Meera Sethi, respectively. Additionally, Bissonauth will contribute an exhibition essay for Divya Mehra’s next solo exhibition, winner of the Sobey Art Award in 2022. Select artist interviews, exhibition reviews, and book reviews appear in  Art Asia Pacific, Art India, C Magazine,  and Women + Performance. Bissonauth is the current Reviews Editor for the peer-reviewed journal ADVA (Asian Diasporic Visual Cultures and the Americas).Cost: FreeThis event is presented on Zoom. You only need to register once per device.AGE GROUP: |
Cambridge Art Galleries |

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

Step back in time and experience the warmth and charm of a heritage kitchen with our Holiday Candy Making Party. Enjoy time with friends around the fire and join in an old fashioned candy making party. Learn to make sweet treats like sugarplums, maple cream fudge, and participate in an old-fashioned taffy candy pull. Take home a box of your treats and end the experience around the open fire making popcorn and drinking hot cocoa.This is an adults only event. Bring a date, a friend, or make new friends at this fun hands on workshop.Whether you're an aspiring cook, history enthusiast, or simply seeking a unique culinary experience, our workshop offers a sweet taste of the past.Registration required.Presenter: Carolyn BlackstockInformation for Museum MembersRegion of Waterloo Museums Member pricing: 10% off with codeEnter the code “memcode” into the discount field and select "Apply" to get member pricing.Please note that your membership must be valid upon booking and on the event date, or access may be denied.

description: Join us for the Zumbathon® Fundraising for Mental Health event on Sun Nov 26, 2023, at 12:30 PM. This exciting event will take place at 212 South Street, Cambridge, ON N1R 2P4.Get ready to dance, sweat, and have a blast while supporting a great cause! Our Zumbathon® is a fun-filled fitness party that aims to raise awareness and funds for Self Help Peer Support mental health services. Whether you're a seasoned Zumba® enthusiast or new to the dance fitness craze, this event is for everyone. Our talented instructors will lead you through energetic Zumba® routines, combining Latin and international music with easy-to-follow dance moves. It's a fantastic way to get active, burn calories, and uplift your mood, all while contributing to a cause that matters.Come with your friends, family, or join solo – everyone is welcome! Together, we can make a difference in the lives of those affected by mental health challenges. So put on your dancing shoes and let's groove for a worthy cause at the Zumbathon® Fundraising for Mental Health event!

eventName: Trivia with a Side of Beer
description: Trivia and beer are coming to KSWRM! Jeff & Miranda’s Trivia Nights and TWB will be here!Trivia and beer are coming to KSWRM! Jeff & Miranda’s Trivia Nights are at Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum! Tickets include one 16 oz. beer from Together We’re Bitter (TWB)’s selection of craft beers, plus access to museum exhibits. Delicious TWB craft beers will be available for purchase during the event. Prizes will be awarded to the highest scoring team, including a hotel stay in St. Jacob's!Region of Waterloo Museums Member pricing: 10% off with code- Enter the code “memcode” into the discount field and select "Apply" to get member pricing.- Please note that your membership must be valid upon booking and on the event date, or access may be denied.BYOF – Bring Your Own Food! Trivia-goers are welcome to bring their own outside food to munch on while playing!Free parking available. Do not drink and drive. This is a 19+ event. Tickets must be purchased in advance, through Eventbrite. No refunds, transfers, or exchanges.Jeff & Miranda’s Trivia Nights are run by – you guessed it – Jeff and Miranda! A fantastic and welcoming trivia team, based out of Kitchener - Waterloo, they provide awesome general and music trivia.Opened in 2016, TWB focuses on maintaining a well-rounded lineup of high quality, approachable craft beers in order to invite more people to share in what they love. A worker-owned co-operative, TWB shows how craft beer and community can support each other.

Ask yourself a few simple questions….Our hope is that you answered, “Yes,” to all of the above questions, and that’s what we love about food: It is a common bond we all share, a single thread that when talked about, brings to mind all sorts of stories and experiences that we can share.Farmers’ markets are a centre of commerce and socializing, a venue for combining old with new and a place for new ideas to be explored and celebrated.The Cambridge Farmers’ Market (CFM) is our community food hub. It is where residents gather to talk about food and community happenings. It’s where awareness is built and the beginnings of change takes place.The CFM dates back to the 1830s with the current market building holding its seat on Dickson Street since 1887. The presence of the market in conjunction with other civic structures, the Town Halls, is an English tradition that is as relevant today as it was when the market was built.The CFM building’s continued use as a market is unique in Ontario. While other markets either remain outdoors only or have had their original buildings converted for other uses, the CFM has continued to flourish in its original location in its original building for its original intended use and this should be celebrated.As you explore the market, the sweet and spicy aromas of hot prepared foods and snacks will tempt you, along with an extensive selection of cheeses, chutneys, pies, confections, specialty oils, preserves, and seasonal fruits and vegetables.A wide range of local growers and food producers can supply you with all your needs from savoury appetizers to mouth-watering desserts.Our market wouldn’t exist without those dedicated vendors, some of whom have been a part of our team for over 50 years. They arrive in the snow and in the rain, or in the heat of summer, often setting up as early as 3:30 in the morning and many don’t pack up until more than 12 hours later.We have 26 year-round vendors and 30 seasonal vendors, averaging 56 vendors at the peak of the market season, who supply approximately 35,000 shopper visits each year.You can learn more about our vendors by visiting the vendor directory on our website, cambridgefarmersmarket.ca.The Cambridge Farmers' Market is open Saturdays from 7 am to 1 pm, year-round. It is located at the corner of Ainslie Street and Dickson Street, in the heart of downtown Cambridge, and parking is available nearby.For more information, visit cambridgefarmersmarket.ca

Ho Ho Ho! Santa Claus is coming to town, and he's stopping by the Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum for a festive Pancake Breakfast Party that's perfect for children of all ages!Santa himself will be making a special appearance, so bring your holiday wishes and get ready to snap some memorable photos with the jolly old man in red.Our expert chefs will be whipping up a mouth-watering selection of pancakes to satisfy your taste buds. Fluffy and golden, they'll be served hot and fresh, making for the perfect holiday treat.Let your creativity shine as you decorate your pancakes with a variety of delectable toppings. From syrup and chocolate chips to whipped cream and fresh berries, you can customize your pancakes just the way you like them!Enjoy a selection of beverages, including coffee, hot chocolate, and juice, to accompany your scrumptious pancakes.Beyond the pancake breakfast, there will be seasonal crafts, games, and activities for the little ones to enjoy, making it a morning filled with merriment.Ticket Information:Adults: $20 Children (under 12): $15 (membership 10% discount applies)Don't miss this chance to create lasting holiday memories with your family and friends. Get into the festive spirit at the Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum's Pancake Breakfast Party with Santa on December 2! Be sure to book your tickets in advance, as this event is sure to be a sell-out. Reserve your spot today for a morning of joy, delicious pancakes, and cherished moments with Santa Claus himself. See you there!

The weather may be frightful, but our Wintry Crafternoons are nothing but delightful! We will be holding our family friendly Wintry Crafternoons every weekend in December from 12 until 4 pm to celebrate the winter season! Our Crafternoons are included in the price of admission, enjoy a wonderful craft and tour of our historic house in its coziest season!Love snowball fights but hate getting soggy socks? Join us December 2nd or 3rd to create a “Snowman pom pom launcher” that brings the fun of snowball fights indoors!Roll up your sleeves and get ready for messy play on December 9th and 10th when we make “Melted Snowman Slime”!Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow! On December 16th and 17th we will be creating “Hanging Beaded Snowflakes” that are sure to add winter charm to your home.Join us December 23rd to create your very own “Wooden Bead Snowman” that makes a fantastic ornament or use your imagination and create your own custom holiday card to give to someone special in your life!We hope to see you at Schneider Haus this holiday season!

Experience the Magic of the Season at Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum!Join us for a Family-Friendly December Extravaganza!  Are you ready for an unforgettable, winter wonderland adventure? The Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum is proud to present a one-of-a-kind, family-oriented event that will light up your holiday season!Step Back in Time and immerse yourself in the enchanting charm of a historic village adorned with festive decorations. Stroll through our picturesque streets, where yesteryear comes alive, and holiday traditions are beautifully preserved. Gather around the crackling campfires with your loved ones and enjoy the age-old pleasure of toasting marshmallows and crafting scrumptious s'mores. The cozy warmth of the fire will keep you snug and merry. Sip on rich, velvety hot chocolate, the perfect medicine to warm your soul on a chilly December evening. Customize your drink with an array of delectable toppings, creating a sweet masterpiece just for you. Indulge your sweet tooth with an array of candies and treats. Discover candy canes, chocolates, and more that will make your taste buds dance with delight. It's a candy lover's paradise!Bring the entire family for an evening of laughter and joy! Father Christmas himself will make a special appearance, ready to listen to your children's holiday wishes and spread the spirit of Christmas.Enjoy festive tunes and live entertainment, take part in arts and crafts, and embark on a scavenger hunt through the village. There's something for everyone to delight in!Don't miss out on this heartwarming, winter extravaganza that combines the best of the season's traditions and a dash of historic charm! Create magical memories with your family and make this December one to remember.Get your tickets today and let the holiday spirit warm your heart! Join us at the Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum for an unforgettable family experience.Ken Seiling Waterloo Region Museum - Where History Meets the Magic of the Season!
